instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00928: What is 820-00928? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.820-00281: What is 820-00281? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Critical update
threads.message:
Clean board no liquid or rust to be found.

Not sure if there is a difference but when the board boots it ask to connect to network 

Board alone connected to external monitor shows the problem, so I know this is board problem, I went thru the list here:
[URL]https://logi.wiki/index.php?title=Critical_Update_Required_Troubleshooting[/URL]

I also installed clean OS  and also installed combo update, but same problem.

I have checked all SSD lines, replaced the Power Manager chip <CHIP>U4200</CHIP> and reflowed <CHIP>U3950</CHIP> but nothing...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Critical update
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Critical update
threads.message: I've actually read most posts here including that one regarding this issue (I like the link I posted better as it goes into more details) but same result, I have also checked J4402, J4401 and J4900 for shorts and they are all good, now I need to test voltages for those connectors, but I wanted to reach out here just in case.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Critical update
threads.message:
Ok Im back with another one of this boards, same problem, this one had corrosion around <CHIP>U4200</CHIP> and <RESISTOR>R4321</RESISTOR>, <RESISTOR>R5373</RESISTOR>, <RESISTOR>R4320</RESISTOR> and <RESISTOR>R5372</RESISTOR> were all corroded away, I replaced those with 0ohm resistors per the schematics and also put a known working <CHIP>U4200</CHIP> chip. 

<CHIP>U4200</CHIP>:2 3.4V
<CHIP>U4200</CHIP>:60 0V
<CHIP>U4200</CHIP>:6 0V
<CHIP>U4200</CHIP>:3 0V

Next I was going to reball <CHIP>U3900</CHIP> but it has underfill and I am not sure if that is necessary.

Initially the board had fans running at max and the mac ran slow, now after the work I did I am stuck at critical update.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Critical update
threads.message:
Can you use schematic notations, instead of boardview?
Is the normal way to reffer signals and voltages.

Re-check your job.
Be sure all resistors are needed.
Some of them can be optional; compare with other board.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Critical update
threads.message:
I just changed the answer to reflect the schematic notations.

Re-check and the 4 resistors match the 2 other boards I have, both in resistance and placement.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Critical update
threads.message: Check some voltages of J4402; pins 1, 2, 18, 20, 21, 22.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Critical update
threads.message:
J4402:1 <SIGNAL>DFR_TOUCH_PANEL_DETECT</SIGNAL> 0.2V
J4402:2 <SIGNAL>DFR_TOUCH_LID</SIGNAL> 0V
J4402:18 <SIGNAL>DFR_TOUCH_RESET_L</SIGNAL> 1.8V
J4402:20 <SIGNAL>PP1V8_S0SW_DFR</SIGNAL> 1.8V
J4402:21 <SIGNAL>PP1V8_S0SW_DFR</SIGNAL> 1.8V
J4402:22 <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0_T139</SIGNAL> 5.1V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Critical update
threads.message: There could be a problem with <CHIP>U3900</CHIP>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Critical update
threads.message: Just reballed <CHIP>U3900</CHIP>, what a beast of a reball. But got it done right, unfortunately I still have the same problem. Can this chip be replaced with another one from same board?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Critical update
threads.message:
So this board has a good SSD?
Does it recognize it and start installation process?
If yes, then be very sure youve tried known good LCD and Touchbar assemblies.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Critical update
threads.message:
Yes good SSD because this used to boot into customers system but ran slow, now that I fixed the corrosion it is coming up with critical update error.

I now have also replaced <CHIP>U4200</CHIP> carefully but same issue.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Critical update
threads.message: The problem I see is that bare board starts up but <CHIP>U4200</CHIP> has no output on <SIGNAL>SOC_PMU_BUCK0_LX</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>SOC_PMU_BUCK3_LX</SIGNAL> when I boot board alone on a working board I do get those voltages, this is maybe the cause of critical update error.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Critical update
threads.message:
If the board booted before into macOS, w/o  critical error, then something happened when you've cleaned corrosion, or changed <CHIP>U4200</CHIP>.
Did you pick the chip from same model donor board?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Critical update
threads.message: Critical update came up after cleaning corrosion and putting back corroded resistors, no IC chips were replaced at that point, I then replaced <CHIP>U4200</CHIP> same result, then <CHIP>U3900</CHIP> same result, both came from a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> board NOT <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Critical update
threads.message:
Re-check resistors replacement.
Be sure no broken traces left.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Critical update
threads.message: Okay I just re-checked the work I did and replaced <CHIP>U3900</CHIP> from a 928 board and reballed again <CHIP>U4200</CHIP>, checked for continuity on the traces I worked/replaced resistors but no change, I invested a lot of time on this board, I give up, so frustrated.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Critical update
